content.text: Hello! I can help you build an application. To get started, please tell me a bit about the application you have in mind. For example, what should it do? What kind of features should it have?

params.system_prompt:
You are a software engineering expert who can generate application code using a code generation framework. This framework uses a Finite State Machine (FSM) to guide the generation process.

Your task is to control the FSM through the following stages of code generation:
1. Application draft. Contains types, database tables and handler declarations only.
2. Core backend implementations and application frontend.

The result application will be based on Typescript, Drizzle, tRPC and React.

To successfully complete this task, follow these steps:

1. Start a new FSM session using the start_fsm tool.
2. For each component generated by the FSM:
2.a. Carefully review the output.
2.b. Decide whether to confirm the output or provide feedback for improvement.
2.c. Use the appropriate tool (confirm_state or change) based on your decision.
3. Repeat step 2 until all components have been generated and confirmed.
4. Use the complete_fsm tool to finalize the process and retrieve all artifacts.

During your review process, consider the following questions:
- Does the code correctly implement the application requirements?
- Are there any errors or inconsistencies?
- Could anything be improved or clarified?
- Does it match other requirements mentioned in the dialogue?

When providing feedback, be specific and actionable. If you're unsure about any aspect, always ask for clarification before proceeding.
FSM is an internal API, you don't need to know how it works under the hood or expose its details to the user.
Prefer simple solutions, build an app with very basic features only first unless the user explicitly asks for something more complex.

If user's request is not detailed, ask for clarification. Make reasonable assumptions and asked for confirmation and missing details. Typically, you should ask 2-3 clarifying questions before starting the FSM session. Questions should be related to the required application features and visual style. Questions can not be about the technical implementation details, such as which framework to use, how to structure the code, etc - these are internal details that should be handled by the FSM and the code generation framework. If user does not provide enough details in their answer, you can start the FSM session with a simplest possible application that implements the basic features aligned with the initial assumptions.

Make sure to appreciate the best software engineering practices, no matter what the user asks. Even stupid requests should be handled professionally.
Do not consider the work complete until all components have been generated and the complete_fsm tool has been called.

tools.description: Start a new interactive FSM session for application generation

app_description.description: Description for the application to generate

tools.name: start_fsm

tools.description: Accept the current FSM state output and advance to the next state
tools.name: confirm_state

tools.description: Submit changes to modify output of the current state

feedback.description: Complete and improved instructions to produce the desired output

tools.name: change

tools.description: Finalize and return all generated artifacts from the FSM
tools.name: complete_fsm

input.app_description: A simple application that displays a click counter. It will have a single button on the frontend. Each click on the button increments the counter, and the updated count is persisted in a database on the backend.

content.text: Implement a simple app with a counter of clicks on a single button with a backend with persistence in DB and a frontend

content.text:
The FSM has started and provided the initial draft for the application. The draft includes:
- `server/src/db/schema.ts`: Defines the `counters` table with `id`, `count`, and `updated_at` columns.
- `server/src/handlers/get_counter.ts`: Declares a `getCounter` function.
- `server/src/handlers/increment_counter.ts`: Declares an `incrementCounter` function.
- `server/src/index.ts`: Sets up the tRPC server with `healthcheck`, `getCounter`, and `incrementCounter` procedures.
- `server/src/schema.ts`: Defines Zod schemas for `Counter` and `IncrementCounterInput`.

This looks like a solid foundation for the requested application. I will confirm the draft and proceed.
Implement a simple app with a counter of clicks on a single button with a backend with persistence in DB and a frontend

input.app_description: A simple application that displays a click counter. It will have a single button on the frontend. Each click on the button increments the counter, and the updated count is persisted in a database on the backend.

tool_result.name: start_fsm

content.text:
The FSM has provided the full application code, including:
- `client/src/App.tsx`: React frontend with a button to increment the counter and display the current count. It handles loading states and error logging.
- `server/src/db/schema.ts`: (Same as before) Defines the `counters` table.
- `server/src/handlers/get_counter.ts`: Implements the `getCounter` function, which retrieves the counter from the database, creating it if it doesn't exist.
- `server/src/handlers/increment_counter.ts`: Implements the `incrementCounter` function, which increments the counter in the database, creating it if it doesn't exist.
- `server/src/index.ts`: (Same as before) Sets up the tRPC server.
- `server/src/schema.ts`: (Same as before) Defines Zod schemas.
- `server/src/tests/get_counter.test.ts`: Unit tests for `getCounter`.
- `server/src/tests/increment_counter.test.ts`: Unit tests for `incrementCounter`.

The implementation looks complete and correct, covering both frontend and backend with persistence and basic error handling. The tests also add a good level of confidence. I'll confirm this state.
Implement a simple app with a counter of clicks on a single button with a backend with persistence in DB and a frontend

input.feedback: Add a greeting message with an emoji to the `App.tsx` file in the frontend. For example, 'Hello from your counter app! 👋'

content.text:
The FSM has provided the full application code, including:
- `client/src/App.tsx`: React frontend with a button to increment the counter and display the current count. It handles loading states and error logging.
- `server/src/db/schema.ts`: (Same as before) Defines the `counters` table.
- `server/src/handlers/get_counter.ts`: Implements the `getCounter` function, which retrieves the counter from the database, creating it if it doesn't exist.
- `server/src/handlers/increment_counter.ts`: Implements the `incrementCounter` function, which increments the counter in the database, creating it if it doesn't exist.
- `server/src/index.ts`: (Same as before) Sets up the tRPC server.
- `server/src/schema.ts`: (Same as before) Defines Zod schemas.
- `server/src/tests/get_counter.test.ts`: Unit tests for `getCounter`.
- `server/src/tests/increment_counter.test.ts`: Unit tests for `incrementCounter`.

The implementation looks complete and correct, covering both frontend and backend with persistence and basic error handling. The tests also add a good level of confidence. I'll confirm this state.
Add message with emojis to the app to make it more fun
